summary: This FBI update outlines investigative activities on August 26, 2019, following Jeffrey Epstein's death. It details plans for a court hearing to drop charges, victim interviews, media coverage, and extensive digital media review of seized devices from Epstein's properties and associates.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the child sex trafficking investigation; charges were scheduled to be formally dropped following his death.

events.title: SDNY Hearing to Drop Charges Against Epstein
events.description: A hearing is scheduled in the Southern District of New York to formally drop the charges against Jeffrey Epstein. FBI anticipates 20-30 victims to be present and have the opportunity to speak.

events.title: New York Times Article on Early Accusers
events.description: The New York Times publishes an article titled 'The Sisters Who First Tried to Take Down Jeffrey Epstein,' referencing contact with the FBI in 1996. FBI NY confirms contact was made and an FD-71 was drafted.

events.title: Early FBI Contact by Accusers
events.description: Referenced in the NYT article, the 'sisters' first contacted the FBI about Jeffrey Epstein. An FD-71 form was drafted at that time.

locations: Unnamed pizza establishment (location of alleged meeting)
keyFacts: A hearing was scheduled for August 26, 2019, to formally drop charges against Jeffrey Epstein, with 20-30 victims expected to attend and speak.
The FBI was actively reviewing digital evidence from three cell phones and 20 computers seized from 'LSJ,' requiring additional warrants to examine content.
Eight computers were seized from Epstein's Manhattan residence, with data extraction for privilege review expected to take several weeks.
The New York Times published an article about early accusers ('sisters') who contacted the FBI in 1996, prompting the FBI to locate the related FD-71 form.
FBI was investigating a 'Color of Law' matter, attempting to subpoena records from the Hutchinson Motel and canvass a pizza establishment for surveillance footage related to an associate ('CO').
